Based on my search results, I can provide comprehensive information about the Polish translation of "Animal Farm" ("Folwark zwierzęcy") and its reception, symbolism, and interpretation among youth in Poland.

## Translation History

The first translation of Animal Farm into a Slavic language – in fact, into any language! – was into Polish. It was made by Teresa Jelenska, the wife of a Polish diplomat, and published at the turn of 1946 and 1947 in London by the League of Poles Abroad.

The Polish title "Folwark zwierzęcy" literally translates to "Animal Farm" or "Animal Manor."

## Historical Context and Symbolism

Between 1952 and 1957, the CIA, in an operation codenamed Aedinosaur, sent millions of balloons carrying copies of the novel into Poland, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia, whose air forces tried to shoot the balloons down. This demonstrates the significant political importance of the work during the Cold War era.

Polish samizdat comics of Orwell's Animal Farm. The original novel was banned in the Communist countries, but in 1985 two comics version were published underground in Poland. This one was published by "Gilosz & Azyl", that refers to the creator and the publisher, however the first remained unknown.

## Contemporary Reception and Interpretation

The work has maintained relevance in modern Poland:

Orwellowska antyutopia w formie pop teledysku dotyka jeszcze bardziej, bo pokazuje jak bardzo współczesny jest ten tekst, który liczy już 80 lat. Tyle czasu minęło od jego pierwszej publikacji, a on wciąż, przez kolejne lata jak mało które dzieło literatury dosadnie i bardzo trafnie diagnozuje rzeczywistość. Przez kolejne dekady nawet na chwilę nie stracił na swojej aktualności, niestety.

(The Orwellian dystopia in the form of a pop music video touches even more deeply, showing how contemporary this text remains after 80 years. So much time has passed since its first publication, yet it continues, year after year, like few works of literature, to accurately diagnose reality. Through the decades, it hasn't lost its relevance for even a moment, unfortunately.)

## Educational Use and Youth Interpretation

George Orwell to pseudonim pisarza angielskiego (prawdziwe nazwisko: Eric Arthur Blair), znanego przede wszystkim z dwu pub­likacji: Folwark Zwierzęcy i Rok 1984, poświeconych refleksji nad zagrożeniami płynącymi z systemu totalitarnego, w którym władza narzuca obywatelom swoją wizje rzeczywistości, jest bezkarna i czer­pie korzyści kosztem podporządkowanych sobie obywateli. Inspiracją do tego rodzaju twórczości były wiadomości przenikające z obszaru ówczesnego Związku Radzieckiego.

(George Orwell is the pseudonym of an English writer known primarily for two publications: Animal Farm and 1984, devoted to reflection on the threats coming from a totalitarian system in which the authorities impose their vision of reality on citizens, are unpunished, and derive benefits at the expense of subordinated citizens. The inspiration for this type of work was news coming from the Soviet Union.)

## Cultural and Academic Analysis

With reference to Max Weber's methodology of ideal types, and following the inquires of Sowa (2011), Leder (2014) and Hryniewicz (2015), as well as with reference to contemporary research on education in Poland, I distinguish three types of cultural codes: the folwark, the totalitarian and the modernisation code.

The term "folwark" itself has special significance in Polish culture, referring to a type of feudal estate system, which adds another layer of meaning to the Polish translation.

## Polish Literary Context

Interestingly, While Reymont never explicitly said that The Revolt was an allegory for the Bolshevik Revolution, it was interpreted as such by literary critics and casual readers alike. This was partly because Reymont's distaste for Marxism was well known.(no content)Bunt (Revolt), published in 1924 by Polish Nobel laureate Władysław Reymont, has a similar premise to Animal Farm. This suggests that Polish readers had a pre-existing literary framework for understanding animal allegories about revolution and totalitarianism.

## Symbolism and Youth Reception

The work's symbolism resonates particularly strongly in Poland due to the country's direct experience with totalitarianism. Orwell pisal: ,,Folwark zwierzecy mial byc przede wszystkim satyra na rewolucje rosyjska. (Orwell wrote: "Animal Farm was meant to be primarily a satire on the Russian revolution.")

The novel serves as an educational tool for Polish youth to understand:
1. The mechanisms of totalitarian control
2. The corruption of revolutionary ideals
3. The importance of critical thinking and resistance to propaganda
4. The universal nature of power corruption

Jako ludzie wciąż cierpimy z namiętności do władzy, budujemy hierarchie, chcemy rządzić i ustalać zasady. I rzadko wyciągamy lekcje z jaskrawych doświadczeń totalitaryzmów i reżimów.

(As humans, we still suffer from the passion for power, we build hierarchies, we want to rule and establish rules. And we rarely draw lessons from the glaring experiences of totalitarianisms and regimes.)

The Polish reception of "Folwark zwierzęcy" demonstrates how the work transcends its original context to become a powerful tool for understanding and critiquing authoritarian systems, particularly resonant for a nation that experienced both Nazi and Soviet totalitarianism firsthand.
